PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the selective leaks of your cabinet submission regarding the French tests over the weekend and your radio comments today that you had `an absolutely clear conscience in terms of what I put to cabinet'—all designed to demonstrate that the `tickle my tummy' response of the government was not your fault and with the implication that the real lack of leadership and judgment lies not at your feet but those of the Prime Minister. In order that the Australian people might apportion blame and to be fair to the Prime Minister after your weekend briefings, will you now table your cabinet submission? Will you explain why cabinet did not resolve to send a delegation to France before the announcement of President Chirac when there was just a chance that it might have done some good?
—Senator Hill knows perfectly well that I don't and won't comment on cabinet processes—
—But you have been leaking it all weekend.

—Either what goes to cabinet or what is discussed there. And that remains my position; it always has been my position. The processes that cabinet went through, as always, were collective processes and, as always, they are being implemented with the collective support of all members of the cabinet.

PARA.TAB: The particular package of decisions that we reached as to an initial response the first time round was perfectly appropriate and proportionate to the nature of the problem as we then perceived it to be, as was the government's response at all levels. In subsequent developments as they occurred, which we foreshadowed at the time of the original announcement with the Prime Minister foreshadowing a South Pacific island consultation process, with me foreshadowing a process of direct communication with the French, as those events took place and further unfolded, cabinet decided, collectively again, that it was appropriate to go down a further path.

Our conscience, my conscience, is perfectly clear on the particular contributions that I have made at all stages to this particular process. What I ought to be asking of the opposition is how its conscience is on this particular matter. Haven't we had enough hypocrisy and opportunism from those opposite?

When I and the Labor Party were marching for nuclear disarmament all those years ago, the coalition was demanding more and bigger bombs. When I and the Labor Party were marching against Vietnam, the opposition was supporting a bloody and indefensible war to the last conscript. When the Labor government was putting in place the South Pacific nuclear-free zone treaty, the coalition was arguing against that, saying that it would offend the United States, that it would offend France, that it would be wrong in principle, the wrong treaty at the wrong time. The member for Mayo, the now shadow foreign minister, said that the problem with the South Pacific nuclear-free zone treaty was that, basically, it was an anti-French treaty and nothing else.

When I was busting my guts out all last year and before with a first-class team of Australian diplomats to get the NPT, the non-proliferation treaty, indefinitely extended, the opposition was railing against treaties of all kinds, saying that they limited and undermined Australia's sovereignty. When I and my party were wrestling with the great dilemma of whether and how we should be selling uranium to ensure that it would only be used for peaceful purposes, that it would not despoil the environment, the coalition's only concern was for the profits of the mining industry.

When I am wrestling now, as I am, with how to recover something by a mixture of protest and persuasion from the wreckage of a very bad decision by the French government—bad for the NPT, bad for the CTBT, bad for the people of the South Pacific—all the opposition can do is try again to score cheap political points, hoping that people will forget its abominable record on everything to do with nuclear issues that any of them had to do with these issues since they came into public life.

The people have longer memories and better memories than the opposition thinks. They will not forget the role the coalition has played over so many decades in nuclear policy. What I and the Labor Party have been religiously pursuing all these years is a three-fold policy on nuclear matters: first, to stop the spread of nuclear weapons to other countries via the non-proliferation treaty; secondly, to stop the development of new generations of weapons by a comprehensive test ban that would ban all testing for all time; and, thirdly, to work for the total elimination of existing nuclear stockpiles. The opposition, the coalition, its individual members, including those who are waxing hypocritical and indignant at the moment, have never worked for any of those objectives. They have never believed in any of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to hear that the minister's conscience is clear. There was only one beneficiary or intended beneficiary of the cabinet leaks of last weekend. I ask specifically: at the cabinet meeting in question which was the subject of those leaks before the announcement of President Chirac, what did cabinet decide to do in terms of preventative action before such announcement was made?
—The government decided that the Prime Minister should write directly to President Chirac, making the point very explicitly and very clearly and arguing the case—
—Was the letter written before?

—The letter was written after that cabinet meeting, as I recall it, later in that week. The cabinet meeting was on 5 or 6 June. The letter was a natural further development of that. We had some discussions as to whether I should write a letter as well, covering that particular territory to Monsieur Juppe or to my counterpart, but it was decided that it would be most effective, since I had only spoken to those people a couple of weeks earlier, for the Prime Minister to write. So that was the immediate, pre-emptive action that we took.

PARA.TAB: We were anticipating that a decision could be made literally at any time along the lines that in fact it was made. We made accordingly a cabinet decision to anticipate a response that would be an appropriate initial response. That is what happened, and as the situation further developed we took a further course of action through direct contact by me with the foreign minister by phone and through direct contact with the delegation, by me again in Paris with South Pacific Islanders. In response to our inability to move the French on the basic issues, we have taken further action now. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Palau led by the Speaker of the House of Delegates, Speaker the Hon. Surangel Whipps. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and hope that your stay here will be both productive and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I note that the historic Accord Mark VIII `Sustaining Growth, Low Inflation and Fairness' was agreed by the government and the ACTU last Thursday. Could the minister inform the Senate of the outcomes from this Accord, and what are the implications for Australia's economic outlook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table Accord Mark VIII `Sustaining Growth, Low Inflation and Fairness'. I table as well a joint statement by the Prime Minister and the President of the ACTU issued on 22 June on the Accord. I think the best way of answering the question from Senator Wheelwright is to quote from the joint statement. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: This new agreement, Accord Mark VIII, will provide a framework for another four years of low inflation, high productivity, high growth and sustained falls in unemployment.

It continues the tradition of underpinning industrial harmony and social justice with an ongoing process of industrial relations and workplace reform and the move to decentralised wage fixing based upon an effective award safety net.

The eighth Accord between the Government and the ACTU is proof that the relationship works and has resulted in the most successful social, economic and industrial relations partnership anywhere in the world.

The strength and efficacy of the Accord relationship is demonstrated, I believe, by the comprehensive nature of the shared objectives pursued by the Accord. They are: sustainable economic growth; a minimum of 600,000 jobs target during the course of the Accord; a commitment to five per cent unemployment being within reach of the government by the end of the decade; a low underlying inflation rate of two per cent to three per cent on average over the economic cycle to ensure continued economic prosperity; continued micro-economic reform and workplace reform; greatly increased national savings to provide a better retirement income for all workers; and an adequate social wage and a commitment to sustainable real wages growth to improve the living standards of all Australians.

PARA.TAB: The Accord includes the four safety net wage increases comprising the third $8 a week agreed in the previous Accord and three annual adjustments of $9 to $12 available at the award level. For low paid workers the range will be $11 to $14 a week annual increase.

The parties are strongly committed to the extension of enterprise bargaining to improve the effectiveness, efficiency, productivity and competitiveness of workplaces in Australia. That commitment is there in detail; it is there in black and white. I can only assume that those who have criticised the productivity elements of the Accord have not read page 4 of the Accord document which makes this very plain.

Mr President, this is unambiguous good news for the economy, business and the workplace. It is in sharp contrast to the old-style confrontationalist approach that the opposition still clings to in its harkings back to Jobsback, one of the most regressive social documents ever to be entered into in the Australian industrial relations debate. I believe the opposition is just incapable of understanding the benefits of working with rather than against the Australian work force. It has opposed all wage increases since 1983, and it has rejected socially innovative projects to assist the most disadvantaged. It still clings to greater expenditure cuts which would be regressive and destructive.

The Accord has served Australia well. This is another instalment on that path, another milestone in social cooperative behaviour in order to deliver fundamental economic change to Australia and to bring about prosperity to Australians wherever they are—and fairly and equally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. On the basis of his final sentence, could I ask the minister to explain to the Senate what the Accord has achieved over the period since 1983?

—As I was saying, the Accord has achieved a massive reduction in strike activity, an ongoing level of high industrial growth and a major cut in inflation from 11.3 per cent down to what is now the ruling level of inflation underlying rate, 1.9 per cent. It has achieved a higher disposable household income per capita in Australia of about 38 per cent, and it has achieved a degree of consensus finding and social harmony necessary to build a competitive world economy.

PARA.TAB: There are other statistics one can quote about the Accord. Perhaps its most enduring achievement has been to end warfare in the workplace, and bring about cooperation in building a more competitive economy in Australia by working with workers on the basis of mutual respect and understanding and capturing their innovative contribution to employment growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I note from reading this morning's Australian your extremely precious comment that you find it totally offensive to suggest you may have put personal interest ahead of the national interest. I also note your claim that any UN resolution condemning the French action would provoke a strong reaction from the French and the francophone states, presumably the very purpose of Senator Faulkner's suggestion. Doesn't your determination to roll over on the one proposal which might galvanise the French into some constructive action make it abundantly clear that you simply do not want to alienate a potentially very powerful support base? Given your obvious and massive conflict of interest on this fundamental issue, why will you not rule yourself out for United Nations Secretary-General, a position which must in any event be a very long shot, or is it the fact that your constant globetrotting, broken only by reluctant returns to question time, has caused you to lose sight of the political woods for the diplomatic trees?

—Mr President, I do find it totally offensive any suggestion that there is a conflict of interest here that would lead me to place any personal conceivable interest ahead of my perception of Australia's national interest. I not only find it totally offensive; it is totally inaccurate on all available evidence as anyone who knows me or knows the circumstances of my involvement in this whole process from the outset knows.

PARA.TAB: As to the particular question, I am happy to answer any specific question you put to me; but if you put snide, sneering, defamatory innuendo like that, I can only respond in this way. Your question is totally without foundation, it is totally offensive, it is totally defamatory and it is totally at odds with everything I have stood for in the conduct of this position in the seven years that I have occupied it. As to what it might be possible to pursue in the General Assembly or, for that matter, any of the other multilateral agencies or forums within the UN system or alongside it, that is a matter we are keeping under very close review, and seeing what might be possible in each one.

The point about a full scale, full-on resolution sought to be initiated in the General Assembly is that it would most likely not succeed—not get up. It is not that it would not get up anyone's nostrils, of course it would, but it might not succeed in being passed at all, because of the combination of forces. From our knowledge of the way these places work—I bow to Senator Alston's superior knowledge of the dynamics of these situations—and from the advice available to me, it is more likely than not that there would be a combination of European, Francophone and nuclear weapons states' resources lined up against us.

Also, to the extent that any such resolution would need to address the problem of Chinese testing as well, because there is no moral, practical or political distinction between those two, you have a great deal of difficulty in mobilising—on all past experience—sufficiently large majorities to carry the day or, at least, to carry it without so many abstentions that the whole exercise is seen as a failure. It is a matter of judgment that you have to make at each step of the way, before you embark upon such exercises, as to what is likely to be productive and what is likely to be either unproductive or counterproductive.

We had such an exercise mounted a few years ago in relation to New Caledonia. You would not remember, Senator Alston, because you do not take any notice of these things except when they involve vulgar opportunities to point score. In the New Caledonia exercise the vote was won, but with so small a margin with so many abstentions, as I recall, that it was seen as a hollow and empty exercise, and one that rebounded upon its promoters. That is part of the difficulty you have to be cognisant of when making these judgments.

There are many opportunities to make statements. There may well be opportunities to attach clauses to other resolutions that are going through various agencies. I certainly do not absolutely rule out the possibility of doing something in the General Assembly. That is one of the things we are going to keep under very close review as we see how this situation evolves in the next few weeks and months.

Our object is to try to get change, hopefully in the basic French policy and, beyond that, to bed down the commitment of the nuclear weapons states to signing the comprehensive test ban we have been working ourselves into the ground for, for so long—to your sublime and profound indifference—to get some change in terms of French commitment to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, to get France to commit itself to closing Mururoa, and to get all the rest of the things that are part of the battery of proposals and propositions we have been putting.

That is the context in which that discussion is taking place. It does not in any way reflect a desire on my part to avoid causing offence to anybody. On occasion, that is part of what is absolutely necessary to get a point across. I am sure the measures we passed last week—which amount to the most significant that I can recall of any country imposing against any other country, with which it normally has friendly relations, in a peacetime environment—will have certainly got that message across. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume, when you headed off to France, Senator Evans, rather than coming to question time last week, that you did not expect to carry the day. In other words, it was a gesture. I presume that you do not seriously expect some of the things you have frantically tried to do in the last few days to cause the French to change their behaviour over the next weeks and months. In other words, you have made gestures. So what is wrong with a gesture in the United Nations General Assembly, where you cannot have a binding resolution but, nonetheless, you can make very clear Australia's position? You would not be taking a measured response or simply waiting until the issue has gone off the boil; you would not be keeping the matter under review. You would be showing that you are fair dinkum. Why aren't you prepared to stand up when it counts or do you simply take the advice of Senator Ray that you move on these matters only when you have the numbers?

—There is a difference between a gesture and an empty gesture. There is a difference between a gesture that is productive and effectively conveys the symbolic force of a particular position and a gesture which backfires on you because you do not have the numbers to get it up and you just demonstrate the weakness of your position in the international community. Even Senator Alston would have the intelligence to understanding that distinction.

PARA.TAB: When I went to France last week, it was in pursuit of two objectives. Firstly, it was to convey a protest of a fundamental and serious kind on behalf of the whole South Pacific Forum and to make that clear across the table eyeball to eyeball. Secondly, it was to engage in an exercise in persuasion. It was to persuade them, if humanly possible, to wind back the tests to which they had already committed themselves. If that was going to be impossible, it was to at least persuade them to put on the record commitments to a decent test ban treaty, not just empty rhetoric, commitments to signing the Rarotonga treaty, not standing outside it, and commitments to closing Mururoa. If you do not think that was a useful way for me to spend my time, a useful way for me to represent the government and people of Australia, or a useful way for me to represent the people of the South Pacific, your judgment is as bad as your political morality. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister will be aware that today marks the 50th anniversary of the signing of the UN charter in San Francisco on 26 June 1945. Is the UN still capable, in the light of recent problems in Somalia, Bosnia and Rwanda, of meeting the demands and expectations placed on it? Further, is it the government's view that the UN still deserves the level of international support it has received in the past?

—I could not help but notice at the outset the cynicism, the derision, the guffaws and the contempt that was coming at me from those on the other side in their response to even the asking of that question. We have here a collection of miserable, vulgar opportunists who simply refuse to take seriously some of these larger and greater issues of the day.

PARA.TAB: Today is an important day because it marks the 50th anniversary, on 26 June, of the signing of the United Nations charter at the San Francisco conference. This anniversary is an opportunity to not only celebrate the UN's achievements but also to review its role, to critically evaluate its performance and to weigh that performance in the perspective of the organisation's wider role and its impact on Australia.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This is an important matter, and the minister has a right to be heard in silence.

—I am indebted to you, Mr President. The UN's credibility and effectiveness have been questioned as a result of recent setbacks to its efforts to promote peace, particularly in Bosnia, Somalia and Rwanda. Some have even queried, sensibly, why we should bother with the UN for another 50 years. But concentrating on a few extraordinarily difficult situations where the UN Security Council or, for that matter, organisations like the OAU or NATO have not been able to bring a restoration of peace has tended to unfairly distort the image of the UN. The seeming impotence of UN peace keepers in Sarajevo or Mogadishu should be set against the UN's wider record in peacekeeping, with operations that have been very successful in recent years, like those in Namibia, Cambodia, Mozambique and, more recently still, Haiti.

PARA.TAB: Even in operations such as UNPROFOR in Bosnia, UNOSOM in Somalia or UNIMIR in Rwanda there have been obviously significant humanitarian benefits delivered as a result of the UN's efforts and the efforts of contingents like the Australians, who participated so bravely and effectively in their efforts in Kibuye, Kigali, and right around Rwanda.

The UN's peace operations are really only the tip of the iceberg in terms of the UN's international role. Its work in promoting cooperation to alleviate poverty, to assist the social and economic development of less developed countries and to protect human rights and basic individual freedoms receives much less attention, largely because the work involved requires quiet persistence over many years rather than noisy reportable flourishes.

This broader role for the UN had its origins in debate in San Francisco in 1946, when the Australian delegation led by Doc Evatt led the way in pressing for a mandate for the UN to promote economic and social cooperation. Part of the article's undertaking, which requires member states to pledge themselves to take joint and separate action to achieve such goals as higher standards of living and the like, came to be known as the Australian pledge. As a nation, we are inclined to undervalue some of our achievements, but this is one that should not be undervalued.

On the basis of that provision and others like them in the charter, the UN and its specialised agencies have been in the front line confronting the world's silent emergencies of hunger, ill-health, repression, dispossession and exile. The sad fact is that this task, which has improved the lives of millions of people around the world, rarely meets television's compulsive need for 30-second grabs. I believe that this work does have the strong support of all Australians and should continue to receive it in the decades ahead.

For all its inevitable flaws, the UN is the only universal membership, universally empowered body that we have or are ever likely to have. Looking ahead to its next 50 years, we cannot be governed by the counselling of despair that is always so easily voiced. Our efforts should be fixed on creating a more effective world organisation, building on everything that the international community has learnt about what has gone right about what has gone wrong in the UN's first 50 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister confirm that the Indonesian government has selected Lieutenant-General Herman Mantiri to be the next Indonesian Ambassador to Australia? How can the Australian government consider such an appointment to be appropriate, especially given General Mantiri's uncompromising views on East Timor, including his offensive justification for the Dili massacre as being `quite proper'? Finally, does the minister consider this appointment to be a personal affront to all those Australians—including himself, members of the opposition and me—who objected most strongly to General Mantiri's comments at the time of the Dili massacre?

—I am aware, of course, of the comments made by Major-General Mantiri—as he then was—during a magazine interview in July 1992, including his remark that the November 1991 massacre in Dili was bound to happen and was not a cause for regret. Upon hearing of those remarks at the time, I immediately instructed Australia's then Ambassador to Indonesia, Mr Phillip Flood, to make representations to the Indonesian government conveying our deep disappointment and extreme regret over the remarks. Mr Flood raised that matter with Foreign Minister Alatas, noting that the comments were very regrettable and inconsistent with the expressions of regret that had been made by President Soeharto himself.

PARA.TAB: While Major-General Mantiri's remarks were unquestionably extremely regrettable—and that is being very diplomatically polite—it is a different matter to say that they disqualify him from appointment as Indonesia's ambassador to Australia. The situation is this: it has only been in very extreme situations that have been very rare in Australia's diplomatic history that agrement is withheld; it is only when we consider—and this is normal international practice—a nominee to be so personally and/or so professionally unsuitable as to be incapable of enabling a productive bilateral relationship to be maintained.

Against that background, in deciding not to withhold agrement for General Mantiri, we took into account three considerations. First, there has never been any suggestion that General Mantiri had any personal involvement in the Dili shootings. In fact, at the time of the November 1991 massacre he was Assistant for Planning and Budgeting to the Chief of Army Staff in Jakarta. Secondly, General Mantiri is very well qualified for the job in the sense that he has risen to the highest level of his profession in Indonesia, is well and favourably known to many in government in Australia, particularly in defence, and has visited this country many times. Thirdly, the ambassadorship to Australia is regarded in Jakarta as an extremely important post. General Mantiri was the personal choice of President Soeharto for the job, and there would clearly be major implications for our bilateral relationship—bearing in mind the standard practice that has been applied about agrement principles in the past—if we denied it in this instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer, but I ask: does he not consider that there must be major implications for the relationship between Australia and Indonesia if we do not at least ask the Indonesian government to reconsider and not have somebody as an ambassador who believes that it is quite right and proper to shoot people because `they were demonstrating; they were even yelling things against the government'?

—All these matters were obviously considered by the government, and it has obviously placed us in a difficult situation. But there is no reason to believe other than that those particular remarks—utterly misjudged, utterly ill-guided and utterly unacceptable as they were—were the occasion of a single response. There is nothing to suggest that they represent a more substantial position that he has adopted, let alone one that he has actually implemented. In all the circumstances, the government felt that there was no other course that could be taken, although obviously we are concerned that it was possible on even one occasion for someone to make so ill-guided and so ill-judged a set of remarks as that. But maybe people should not be judged for an entire professional lifetime on the basis of one mistake of that kind.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans. I refer to your statement to the Review and Extension Conference of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty in April of this year when you predicted that `negotiations on the comprehensive test ban treaty are far advanced and most likely to be concluded this year'. Firstly, do you now accept that Australia's refusal to push for strengthened disarmament measures at the disarmament conference, including a commitment to weapons reduction targets, was based on an unrealistic assessment of the willingness of the nuclear weapons states to meet their existing Article VI commitments? Secondly, will Australia's position leading up to the negotiation for the CTBT and the 1997 nuclear non-proliferation treaty preparatory committee meeting be reviewed in the light of the French and Chinese nuclear testing and the United States prevarication about the level of testing that should be permitted under a comprehensive test ban treaty?
—Senator Margetts should not believe anything she reads in the paper, and certainly not anything written by Mr Duncan Campbell, on which that particular question seems to be based.
—How would you know?

—There is more to be said on that subject, perhaps on another occasion. The truth of the matter is that Australia's position on the NPT renewal exercise was one of the most carefully considered and hardest fought for of any country participating in that treaty and most successful in terms of producing the outcome that we all—with the exception, I know, of the Greens—actually wanted: indefinite extension.

PARA.TAB: The only way that indefinite extension could reach agreement and, effectively, unanimous support, as it did, was by the non-nuclear weapons states being satisfied that some pretty serious constraints had been accepted by the nuclear weapons states—in particular, so far as a much-strengthened review process was concerned, in terms of measuring their performance by reference to their Article VI obligations; and, secondly, by a quite substantial set of principles and guidelines and objectives being laid out as to what needed to happen next, not least a very strong commitment being made to a comprehensive test ban treaty.

Non-proliferation by itself only goes so far. What is absolutely crucial is the need to stop new generations of weapons being tested by all tests being banned for all time. That has been an essential Australian foreign policy objective for as long as this government has been in power—it certainly was not under the previous lot—and we have been pursuing it assiduously and effectively. There is no reason to change any of the negotiating positions that we have been supporting. We wanted that CTBT to be negotiated this year rather than next year. We thought at one stage—optimistically—earlier this year that might have been possible. What we did succeed in doing was getting a commitment, which had not hitherto been on the record at all, from most of the nuclear weapons states: firstly, to sign a CTBT, and, secondly, to do it by a finite date; that is to say, by next year. So they were major achievements, and now those achievements have got to be pursued.

Your other question was about what we are doing with the United States to stop it resuming testing. There is no pressure or mood within any segment of the United States government to resume nuclear testing as such. The only argument that you have been reading about in the last week or so is an argument within sections of the US administration as to what the sub-threshold test level ought to be. Most people have acknowledged that it is difficult, because of verification problems and all the rest of it, to have an absolutely zero limit; although, ideally, that is Australia's preferred position—that is what should be in the treaty document.

There has been a suggestion, for example, from the US that explosions of the order of two kilograms worth of TNT ought to be permissible as part of an exercise in stockpile stewardship. Other countries, nuclear weapons states, have been arguing for larger thresholds—including in the case of France, I understand, up to 300 to 500 tonnes worth of explosive potential, which is pretty extraordinary and hard to even begin to think of as not constituting a nuclear test, even though 500 tonnes is still only one-twentieth the size of the minimal explosion we have been used to at Muroroa and elsewhere, which has been in the range of 10 kilotons up to 100 kilotons.

The US argument was all about what that threshold should be. It does seem that that argument has been very much resolved in favour of the commitment to stay right down at the lower end of that scale. That is a healthy development, one that we welcome and one that we will continue to pursue and push very hard indeed. There is no ground whatsoever for believing that the United States is even thinking of resuming any testing proper. That is just not on the agenda. It has not been, and it certainly will not be under this administration, I am fully confident.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. However, I will just read from a press statement by Australia's Ambassador to the United States:

QUESTION.PARA: Australia will not object to small-scale nuclear testing under the test band treaty to ensure the safety of nuclear weapons . . .

Whilst the minister clearly said that various people had various definitions of what `small-scale' is, he mentioned that by `small-scale' France means not what any of us would consider to be `not testing'. So what is the deal, Minister? What have you actually ensured from France by way of a commitment to a decent CTBT? Today, once again, you have downplayed France's plans for limited testing, or what it would call limited testing. You have just made an excuse for France today.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you read the whole transcript of Ambassador Russell's statement on the radio this morning you would have to acknowledge that what he was talking about when he referred to small-scale tests were essentially benchtop, experimental explosions involving no more than of the order of two kilograms of TNT. That is what he said and that is certainly the context in which I think when I think of small-scale possible exemptions. Anything much more than that—certainly, anything in the range of 300 to 500 tonnes—would be totally and comprehensively unacceptable. It would be inconceivable that we could support that and we will certainly be sending an expert mission around the place to argue very vigorously against that. We have a great deal of respect and credibility on those sorts of issues, which is utterly unshared on your side of the table.

PARA.TAB: As to the particular question about what is likely to happen, it is not a matter of acknowledging any virtue at all in the French position. Obviously, what the French have done has been to bring the NPT and the CTBT process into a great deal of difficulty and anxiety for those of us who are concerned to maintain it because they have lost credibility. But at least it can be argued that they have modified their position on the question of threshold tests and it might be possible to get a lower number out of them than was otherwise the case. That is not a ray of sunshine but it is at least one element that needs to be understood. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Within the major OECD countries, Australia has the worst external deficit, the second highest bank prime interest rates, the second highest rate of inflation, and is second only to Spain when it comes to printing money. Now we discover from the Australian Automobile Association that, in the OECD, only Mexico and Greece have car fleets older than Australia's. Can you explain to Australians why they continue to be subject to such punitively high real interest rates? With the benefit of hindsight, can you tell us whether Mr Keating's banana republic statement nine years ago was a warning or was it a promise?

—Mr President, This is what you would call a political question for effect. There is nothing in this question of any real analytical content as far as the economy is concerned. If, Senator Herron, you are concerned about interest rates, since your party will not produce an economic policy—behind the vacuum we find there is but another vacuum—let us compare interest rates from the time when the coalition was in government and what interest rates are now. I did this last week but perhaps you want to hear it again: official interest rates, when Mr Howard left office last time, were 9.9 per cent; current official interest rates are 7.45 per cent. If this question, among all of the subjects that are glossed over, is about interest rates, the truth is that Australia is enjoying historically low levels of interest rates at the present time under us.
—I am asking about real interest rates.

—If the question is, by way of the interjection you have just made, about the level of real interest rates, the difference between real interest rates and nominal interest rates is the expectation of what future inflation might be. At the time of the Howard treasurership under the Fraser government, inflation was at 11.4 per cent or more. When you subtract our low level of inflation from the level of interest rates, okay, you get a little figure there that will delight you, but the truth is that if the comparison is between real interest rates under you and under us, in the wider landscape of the economy, under your government, under your tenure of the Treasury benches, we had high levels of interest, we had high levels of inflation of 11.3 per cent and better, we had massive unemployment of over 10 per cent, and we had negative economic growth.

PARA.TAB: We now have dramatically high levels of job creation. Unemployment is coming down to be within five per cent by the end of this century. We have low underlying inflation of 1.9 per cent at the present time. We have a cooperative work force with low strike levels and a degree of building higher productivity components into the economy. If this question—which is put up for political grandstanding—is about picking on one or two indicators, let us have the full argument. Let us get the fundamentals down.

We have a high profit share in the Australian economy. We have lower levels of unit cost production in the Australian economy at the present time. We now have a level of national savings generated by superannuation which is putting Australia at the level of a net saver, not a net borrower, in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about our overseas debt?

—If the question is about the current account deficit—which, by way of interjection, it has suddenly become—in the time I have left I would love to have a proper discussion with you about the current account deficit. But may I say that comparisons with Mexico which you and your party have made over the weekend are just ludicrous. This is just absolutely off-the-planet sort of stuff. This country has strong political stability and low inflation. It is not in recession. All those things are not true of Mexico. You cannot make a comparison based on current accounts between us and other OECD countries on that basis at all. Get it into perspective.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Drug Testing in the Armed Forces

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. In the light of recent media reports on drug testing in the armed forces could the minister advise the Senate on the status of the introduction of the urinalysis program in the Australian Defence Force?

—For some time the defence forces have been considering random drug tests. Random tests were to be brought to fruition on 1 July this year. The reason for this is that many of the people involved in the defence force are handling lethal weaponry and very sophisticated equipment and therefore a no drugs policy is absolutely essential. From time to time people have been dismissed from the defence force when they have been discovered to have been taking illegal substances. Having made that decision, it has been run by the Privacy Commissioner and the Attorney-General's Department who have come up with some difficulties.

PARA.TAB: The Privacy Commissioner has raised two or three doubts about random drug testing and we will need to consider those. The Attorney-General's Department has indicated that the concept of self-incrimination could also impinge on this particular decision. We made a decision late last week to delay the introduction of the tests on 1 July until we resolve these issues. If there is conflict with existing law or legislation we may have to legislate. I reiterate the necessity for making sure that the armed forces are drug free.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Visit of Secretary-General of Vietnamese Communist Party to Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: will the Secretary-General of the Vietnamese Communist Party, Mr Do Muoi, shortly be making a visit to Australia on the invitation of the Prime Minister and, if so, when? On what basis has Do Muoi been invited and will the Australian taxpayer be required to meet the costs of the visit? Will Do Muoi be treated simply in his capacity as an official of the Vietnamese Communist Party or will he be accorded additional status and treatment and, if so, what? Will any meetings be arranged before the visit between the government and representatives of the 160,000 Australians of Vietnamese origin? Will the Communist Party chief's itinerary include meetings between him and those representatives, including religious representatives, so that he can be left in no doubt as to their views?

—It is the case that Mr Do Muoi has been invited to Australia by the Prime Minister following his very constructive and successful conversations with him during his visit to Vietnam a few months ago. The dates of that visit have not been precisely determined. They will be subject to public announcement in the normal way. As I said in the estimates committee hearing, it is intended to be within the next couple of months.

PARA.TAB: It is the case that Mr Do Muoi is an official of the Communist Party rather than the government, but Senator Short and his ilk have been telling us for years, as if it is a breathtaking revelation, that the Communist Party and the government are indistinguishable in communist societies of this kind. Of course they are, for all practical purposes in terms of policy direction and who determines what in terms of the larger scheme of things.

Mr Do Muoi is an extremely senior and important player and has a very important influence on Vietnamese policy development right across the whole spectrum of issues—political, economic and human rights—in which Australia remains intensely interested. Of course we will be prepared, and I am certainly happy to consult with representatives of the Vietnamese community on their hopes, or expectations or whatever for this particular visit or any particular points they want to put to the government. We are always prepared to listen in this respect.

As to whether Mr Do Muoi's itinerary will include meetings with representatives of that community, that is entirely a matter for Mr Do Muoi himself to determine. No doubt requests will be made by the community. They will be put to him and it is entirely up to him to choose whether he wants those meetings to go ahead. That is a courtesy we extend to all visitors to this country to determine the final shape of their program and who it is they want to expose themselves to. We will not be making any different exception in this particular case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister left unclear the question of the status with which Mr Do Muoi will visit here. I ask him again: could he clarify what status will be accorded Mr Do Muoi while he is here? Who will fund the visit? I must say that I find it extraordinary that after almost two years now the government still cannot give a firm date. Why the continuing delay? Is it simply because you are deliberating deferring the visit until after the federal election?

—As I understand it—but I will need to check this in case I am in anyway misleading—Mr Do Muoi will be given guest-of-government status in the normal way, which means that visitors get themselves to Australia but we cover their costs or costs of a small proportion of the contingent while they are here. That is the normal treatment.

PARA.TAB: As to the precise level, a judgment will be made as to what the appropriate sort of quasi-ministerial level is for a person of that seniority. I am sure there are some ground rules within the protocol system that will determine that. I am not aware of what precise determination has been made and what the precise calibration has been, but Mr Do Muoi is obviously a very senior visitor and will be treated as such.

There has been deliberation, as I understand it, about the date—it just has not been finally settled as to the precise days of arrival and departure and the sequence of events. It is normally the case that these visits are announced rather closer to the time, as has certainly been my practice in any visits that I have hosted. There is no difference in this instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Is the minister aware of the report of the pilchard mortality task force which identifies a virus in dead Australian pilchards, but not in healthy ones, and in imported pilchards? Is the minister aware that this report points to the almost complete lack of information on pilchard diseases and for this reason the extreme difficulty being experienced by researchers in identifying whether this virus is or is not naturally present in the Australian pilchard population? Does the minister recognise that the collection of this fundamental data is very unlikely to attract private funding and that more public funding must be found for public interest and environmental research of this nature? Will he ensure that in next year's budget we will see a considerable expansion of government funding for scientific research in these vital environmental and public interest areas?

—Perhaps I should answer this question by starting with the last point first. The OECD recently brought out figures on what it calls GERD—gross expenditure on research and development. Within the research and development definition, of course, all science expenditure takes place. Within that we can calculate that public sector expenditure on research and development in Australia ranks Australia in the OECD at No. 4. We just jumped over three countries in public expenditure on science, and they were Canada, Italy and Austria. The only countries that are ahead of us that spend more in the public sector on science are the Scandinavian countries. Our ranking in the world now is fourth.

PARA.TAB: That is a situation which obviously we would want to improve on, but by world standards you have to say that this is a government that has committed major funding to public sector research which typically is long-term fundamental research dealing with the issues that I have often heard Senator Coulter speak of about the need to press further with the frontiers of scientific discoveries rather than in terms of applied research. Our problem in this country is applied research. So on the last point you made about funding in the public sector for research, we are ranked fourth in the world—up three spots in the last OECD survey. That is not a bad ranking, although it is one that we would obviously wish to improve on.

Coming to the question of pilchards, I understand that the report to which you refer, and which was also the subject of a question you put to Senator Collins last week, is due to be tabled shortly—I am not exactly sure when. I am aware, broadly, of the study. I am not aware yet, I might say, of what the precise findings might be.

I did have in my brief—but I do not have now, I am sorry to report; I will send for it, and I will supply a copy to you—a report of the work that CSIRO is doing in this area, which makes it clear, by reporting this body of research being conducted by the CSIRO, that Australia is by no means lax in this field. We have a particular project that is conducting fundamental research. It is worth while to the broad industries and to the issue of the pilchards. I do not have that report with me. I will obtain it and make it available to you, either today or tomorrow, as soon as I possibly can.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not impressed with the minister's reply. Is the minister aware that the task force report says that we need urgently more research in the area of public health, oceanography, planktonology, epidemiology, virology and histopathology—just to name a few in relation to this specific outbreak? Minister, will you give an assurance that the poor performance of Australia will be further improved next year?

—I reject the characterisation of Australia's performance as poor. Australia is a well-performed scientific country and is respected around the world as creating new knowledge each year well above the size of what our population or GDP suggests we are capable of. We fight above our weight in the scientific arena and produce more information and valuable research in the world than other countries comparable to us. So it is not a poor record; it is something that Australians should be proud of.

PARA.TAB: In this particular field, I will look at the report when it becomes available. Obviously, research institutes such as the CSIRO and the Australian Institute of Marine Science are institutes that will also examine that report and consider what type of priority they will give to any additional research, should it be required. They will also not take the view that Australia should create all of this research itself. They will take the view of linking with other international research institutes and organisations to take the whole level of world research to a higher plane. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. I refer to comments made by His Excellency the Governor-General in a wide-ranging speech on the occasion of the Arthur Mills oration. I ask: does the government endorse the views His Excellency made whilst commenting on euthanasia? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . having had a full and satisfying lifetime there is a point when the succeeding generations deserve to be disencumbered—to coin a clumsy word—

If not, why hasn't the government disencumbered itself from that comment, which is clearly very insensitive, if not offensive, to those senior citizens within our community who have made a lifelong contribution to building this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —Part of Senator Abetz's question asked whether or not the government would dissociate itself from the comments of the Governor-General. Senator Abetz must understand that those comments were personal comments of the Governor-General and have absolutely nothing to do with government. That is the first thing that needs to be said. The Governor-General's comments were part of a public debate on this issue, but they have nothing to do with the government. So the government is not required one way or another to dissociate itself from those comments.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the question of euthanasia in this country certainly has considerably more weight in that community debate because of the legislation passed by the Northern Territory parliament. There is no doubt at all that there is a change in the community sentiment of whether or not this matter should be discussed. In fact, I think it is now in the public domain for debate like it previously never was. I think that is largely because of the actions of the Northern Territory government.

Thirdly, I cannot tell Senator Abetz reliably what the polling shows, but there is a very significant sympathy in the community not because people want to choose euthanasia for themselves but because they do not want to prevent other people, if they make that decision honourably and properly, from perhaps acting on it. In other words, there is some sympathy in the community for the decision of the Northern Territory government. There is also considerable weight against it. To the extent that it is relevant at all to the Commonwealth government, I think we should recognise that it is a matter for state and territory governments and/or community debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note with some interest that the government saw fit to dissociate itself from Arthur Tunstall's comments, so I assume that the government will not rely on that principle in relation to His Excellency's comments.
—He made a racist comment, you goose!

—The minister is quite right because they were racist comments, and I suggest that His Excellency's comments were very ageist and should not have been supported in this de facto way. I ask the minister: what assurances will you and the government give to the thousands of senior citizens in our community that His Excellency's sentiments will in no way play a role in government policy and decision making in respect of the quote that I just read out?

—Senator Abetz seems not to have heard anything I said. The question of government responsibility for euthanasia is a matter for state and territory governments. The only government that has so far proceeded on this issue is the Northern Territory government. It is a matter of changed community debate because of the Northern Territory government's decision. But I think the hint in Senator Abetz's words that maybe aged people will be frightened or discriminated against is, firstly, to misunderstand, as I understand it, what the Northern Territory legislation on euthanasia is about and, secondly, to whip up concern and anxiety for aged people in this country. This government's commitment to policies, programs, payments, support and retirement incomes for aged people is unquestioned.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The supplementary question was inviting the minister—because it asked about you and the government—to indicate whether she supports that position and whether she is comfortable with what the Governor-General said. If she is happy to be on the public record as associating herself with those remarks, that is fine. But let us be clear that the question was inviting her to express her view and now is her chance to do it.
—You know as well as I do, Senator Alston, that I am not in a position to dictate to the minister how she answers the question, provided she is relevant.

—Mr President, I answered that proposal in the first part of my answer. Senator Alston, it is a good trawl but quite irrelevant. My concern about Senator Abetz's question is that it might make aged or elderly people in this country concerned, and that is something we object to. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I refer to various media comments on the outcome of the minister's Small Business Forum held last Friday. I understand that there was fairly vigorous debate concerning proposed changes to the way in which the issue of unconscionable conduct was dealt with. I ask the minister whether the outcome of the forum is consistent with his policy agenda.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the meeting of the Small Business Forum held here in Canberra last Friday there was an excellent outcome for the forum and for the government over the issue of unconscionable conduct—an issue that has been debated in the small business community for many years. I have previously placed it on the agenda to get an opinion of whether the small business interests in this country—there were some 34 small organisations represented—would give an indication of support that section 51AA of the Trade Practices Act, called the unconscionable conduct section, could be amended to strengthen and give better economic redress to small business in Australia, vis a vis dealings with big business.

PARA.TAB: A report was given by a working party recommending that yes, the act be amended and strengthened accordingly. There was a lengthy discussion. Overwhelmingly, those organisations present recommended in favour of amending the act. Three or four organisations had already gone on the public record showing some concern about the change—unfortunately, they had not looked at all the issues, in my view—and they were: the ACCI, VECCI from Victoria, the Australian Bankers Association and, of course, the Law Council of Australia.

In the end, we reached an agreement where three of those four organisations did not oppose the subsequent resolution moved by the forum. But, in the end, the bankers still opposed any change to unconscionable conduct. I warned them that I thought it was an unfair scare campaign, but they said that any change to unconscionable conduct would weaken contract law in Australia. I said, `The only thing you haven't accused us of doing in looking at changes in this area is saying that this will be the end of christianity or motherhood.'

For too long in this country small business has been at a disadvantage in contract law in dealing with big business. The government is now trying to address this so that there is an even-handed approach. But the Bankers Association is still opposing any change—and they wonder why they have a poor reputation in the small business community in Australia. Friday's opposition to the change was an example of why. The forum passed the following resolution:

ANSWER.PARA: The forum expresses its concern at the ineffectiveness of the unconscionable conduct provision of the Trade Practices Act and encourages the government to strengthen measures against unconscionable conduct. The forum looks forward to contributing to the debate on the most appropriate way in which to do so.

I indicated to the small business organisations that we would have further consultation with them on the actual wording and preparation of a cabinet submission on an appropriate amendment to 51AA, and those discussions are already well under way with them and with other government departments.

PARA.TAB: I also want to briefly mention that at the small business coalition dinner the night before, when I indicated my support, Judi Moylan, the shadow minister, stood up and said that she did not want to deal with the issue of unconscionable conduct, it was too difficult to deal with, she did not have a view about it and she hoped that I would be able to deal with it as a minister and resolve the issue before there was a change of government because she did not want to deal with it. It was an astonishing comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get that rubbish?

—There were 30 people present, go and ask them—they were all present at the dinner. It was an astonishing performance. Some time ago, Senator Boswell warned me that, `On this issue, always be warned: the Liberal Party will play dead on any change to the law that affects small business.' Senator Boswell was absolutely correct. (Time expired)
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I claim to have been misrepresented.
—What on?
—Hold your breath and you will find out.
—You will need to seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—I seek leave.
—It is not a point of order, that's the only thing.
—The only way I could attract the President's attention was to call a point of order, as you would understand, Senator Faulkner.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —An article in today's newspaper has been drawn to my attention. It is headlined, in the most gratuitous way, `Crichton-Browne's showdown at the federal corral'. The day when one would have been called, `Senator Crichton-Browne' or whatever has been well lost.

PARA.TAB: I wish to correct a number of matters contained in that article by Glenn Milne, who in the normal courteous way ignored contacting me to ask my opinion, my views on the veracity of the facts.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the article by Kookaburra in Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald?

—Mr President, there is an interjection about a newspaper article by Kookaburra on Saturday morning. I have to say that I read it superficially but, as my memory serves me, I was but a passive player in and a passive observer of events that were taking place amongst other people. Can I say from the outset that the article—

PARA.TAB: Senator West interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —When matters of this seriousness are raised on that side of the chamber, there is a standard procedure of courtesy where people listen. When people's reputations are impugned or threatened or challenged, there is a temptation out of decency to listen to what they have to say. I am sure that the Labor Party will maintain that respect on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: It is not the most horrific thing that has ever been said about me. I will be indulging myself about those things over the coming week—whether they come from our side or from the Labor Party's side. But for the time being, can I refer you, Mr President, to an article by Glenn Milne. As I understand it, he is not known to be a great lover of the Liberal Party, having had certain contacts on the Liberal Party side. I am not one of them, I might say.

The article starts by referring to `disgraced West Australian Liberal power-broker Noel Crichton-Browne'. I do not know what the contemporary definition of `disgraced' is, but I shall from now on be taking very considerable care to learn what it means. That is how the story starts. It starts in a subjective, editorial way. It goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The behind-the-scenes manoeuvres which blocked Crichton-Browne's political resurrection demonstrates the extent to which the West Australian Liberal numbers' man remains focused on propping up his own power base at the expense of the interests of the federal party and Howard's prospects of victory.

I have not the slightest idea what that means, except to say this. At my own expense, at my own indulgence and at my own risk I had research done in respect of the matter with which we are now all familiar which required me to step down as Deputy President. I believed it was in the best interests of the Senate. In some respects it was in the best interests of the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: The polls—they are indelibly imprinted on my mind—showed the following: 23 per cent of the population approved of the public disclosure of my personal affairs. One might translate that to the personal and public affairs of everybody in this chamber. Sixty-five per cent of the population disapproved. The only thing that disappointed me was that 95 per cent of the population of Western Australia recognised me.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not surprising.

—I was going to make a gratuitous comment about gender, but I shall not do that. The other question was: would your vote be changed in respect of Crichton-Browne as a result of the revelation? Eighty-nine per cent said no; three per cent said yes.

PARA.TAB: That pollster is one of the most sophisticated, well regarded pollsters in Australia. We all know that in Australia voters tend to vote for what is in their best interests, not the high, moral, altruistic ground. It would be the view of every single sophisticated pollster in this country that, had I insisted on remaining number one, irremovable, irrevocably elected number one and unable to be moved, at the time of the election that three per cent would have dissipated into absolutely nothing. The contest was clearly going to be between the two leaders and their competing policies. However, I stepped down because I judged, in the short term, that it was likely to cause internal problems for the party. The article goes on, in a rather obscure way which defies my understanding, to say:

SPEECH.PARA: However, it also reveals the emergence of a group of senior Liberals around Howard whose determination to win now sees them prepared to ruthlessly chop off anybody who threatens those prospects.

No doubt Mr Milne will tell us what it means, but it means absolutely nothing to me, although I will say that if I had chosen to stay No. 1 I would be No. 1 today, and nothing could have changed that. I will go to the next paragraph in the article of relevance to me:

. . . the party by convincing Crichton-Browne to stand down as the number-one Senate ticket-holder following revelations that Crichton-Browne had been the subject of a domestic violence restraining order from his wife.

I do not want to titillate any more than to say this, and I have said it before—and this is a question before the Western Australian practitioners board—my wife never sought a restraining order against her husband. I can say no more than that for the time being because—in the same way I asked the Commonwealth police not to disclose that I was the person who had complained about allegations which required them to visit my office on Friday of last week—I will wait and carry the burden of that matter until such time as due process takes place and those involved in misdemeanours, criminal offences and improper conduct are dealt with. If that means that I have to wear it for the time being, so I shall. The article then goes on:

Despite knowing that Crichton-Browne was adamant about embarking on a course of action that could have torpedoed Howard—perhaps fatally—it appears that no West Australian MP put pressure on Crichton-Browne to reconsider.
All I can say about that is that it was a very wise course of action on the part of my colleagues. The article goes on to say this:
Those around Howard were aghast. They decided Crichton-Browne had to be stopped. This critical task fell to John Moore. A Liberal frontbencher and former Queensland Liberal State president...

And it goes on to say how Moore was a minister in the Fraser government who in some obscure, obscene way was required to step aside over some matter relating to a colour television set when he was, as I recall those days, no more than the minister for customs. There was an obscene notion about ministerial responsibility then, and I am glad to say that there is now a more contemporary view about ministerial responsibility. I say that for both sides of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: Let me tell honourable senators about my relationship with John Moore. I have known John Moore for, I suspect, about 30 years. From time to time we had the dubious distinction of having some influence on who used to be the federal president. I remember getting out of bed one morning at 3 a.m. to make sure that he understood where the votes needed to be. At 6 a.m. he understood what I was saying and I understood what he was saying and God prevailed and the right person was elected. So it is not as if—

TALK.START.PARA: —God was on your side then, in that case.

—God has always been on my side. Sometimes he prevails with travail and difficulty. While I am no Job, I am certain at the end of the day there is a very good cause for me going through this temporary aberration. Let it not be imagined for a moment that John Moore was sent along as an emissary of anybody else to convince me not to proceed with my ambitions on this occasion. He did not dissuade me. I am not reading here; I am just trying to remember the facts as they were at the time. He did not dissuade me one way or another; in fact he never had the slightest idea as to what my intentions were.

PARA.TAB: I will say this about John Moore: he had the decency to come around to discuss the matter with me. I again quote from the article:

SPEECH.PARA: Moore has refused to say what happened at his Canberra lunch...
Let me confirm the one factual matter in this article. We did have lunch—as if that is some unique and special occasion. Then the article goes on:

Over several hours he spelled out not only the political implications of a federal backlash against the West Australian Liberal Party but warned Crichton-Browne of the implications for him as an individual.
I ask you all to think about that carefully. The article goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: The import was clear. If Crichton-Browne insisted, he had to consider the possibility that further poisonous leaks—of the kind that had already crippled his career—could come out.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell you one thing. For a cripple, I feel very agile on my feet. I am not about to be seen to be struggling around. To the great shock and horror of some, my political career either at a federal or state level is not completed, nor is it finished. To suggest there were going to be more poisonous, crude, vulgar, dishonest lies and untruths about me, I found fascinating; because, if people have got something, I am sure they do not leak it out through some insidious, dishonest, dirt sheet report, on our side at least. I imagine that will be put on the record. I cannot imagine what can be said about me that has not already been said, which is more untrue than that which has untruthfully been put so far. To pursue this matter, it appears from this article that Crichton-Browne was not being threatened; he was just being reminded to watch out for the lie of the land. I am pretty capable of watching the terrain—and I will continue to watch it. The article goes on:
The truth of this appeared to be borne out during the tough negotiations in Perth—
I love the colourful adjectives that journalists tend to use—
during which Howard initially told Crichton-Browne he had to go.
No leader ever tells me when I have to go. My history is that I have had to tell a few leaders when they have had to go. The article continues:
Crichton-Browne's wife—
I find this kind of quaint—
Esther was present for some of those negotiations. She made tea for Howard and, given the nature of the discussion, must have maximised the Liberal leader's discomfort.
Can you imagine any Liberal leader discomforted because my wife was making him a cup of tea?

TALK.START.PARA: —Depends what she put in it.

—She put a strong dose of courage in it. I am not referring to courage for him but to courage for decision making. I might also tell you, with indulgence and approval—God forgive me if I get this wrong, and I say this as a Christian—that John Moore also told me that his wife utterly agreed with my wife, when my wife told John Howard over his cup of tea that she totally disapproved of his suggestion that I should step aside. She said I had her full support and I should not be intimidated, threatened, encouraged or coerced into stepping aside. It was her strongest view that I should stay where I was.

PARA.TAB: John Moore tells me that his wife's view—not that his wife's view was terribly important, but it was in the context of this article—was that this had nothing to do with the Liberal Party, the parliament or the collective process of government; it was a private matter and I ought to put aside those who were barking for selfish political reasons and allow our families to get on with our lives and for me to get on with my career.
I want to say two other things before I find myself excited enough to go on at any length. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the lack of political will by the federal organisation to impose itself on the State branch, the Liberals faced going to an election burdened by Crichton-Browne and all his baggage.

I have already referred to the research done thus far. It is with some modesty that I remind at least my side of parliament that I had the dubious distinction of playing a prominent part in Richard Court's last campaign. It was the best conservative vote the Liberal Party in Western Australia had received since Federation. We won six out of 10 Senate spots. On the last occasion we held eight out of 14 federal seats. I do not know a state that does better. I certainly do not know a state that will do better next time.

PARA.TAB: To suggest in some obscure way that I am some sort of baggage I find kind of quaint from Mr Milne, who, to my knowledge, has never crossed the 26th parallel and who has certainly not crossed into WA. If he has, he snuck across without talking to people who have some knowledge of what goes on in politics. I am quite certain that he will not dissuade those who are the beneficiaries of our success by suggesting that Crichton-Browne is baggage in some way.

I will not embarrass my colleagues by going seat by seat into how we did it and the price I paid to make sure that we won the Mount Helena by-election recently. Dare I say that the necessity for me to be implicated in raising sufficient funds to ensure that we had a campaign to win the first seat as a government from an opposition since Federation says something about the standing of the Liberal Party.
