The reform process is very complex and we must be on the lookout for possible anomalies and problems thrown up unexpectedly by this process of competition reform because, with the best will in the world and with the best structures, it is not always possible for governments to see ahead to some of the intricacies of the effects of this sort of legislation.

The measure has had a very long gestation period. I welcome the birth of the national competition reform embodied in this bill. I look forward to its full implementation under the leadership of John Howard in the next coalition government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995. I will begin with a few comments with regard to the consumer elements of the Hilmer reforms. The fact is that various consumer groups have never given anything other than heavily qualified support to the Hilmer reform package. For example, the Australian Consumers Association warned the government that competition in itself was not necessarily a good thing, and unless key design issues were fixed there would continue to be significant failures in the marketplace in regard to competition, efficiency, access, and fairness for consumers.

PARA.TAB: In particular, the association sought to ensure that the bill contains a statement ensuring that the competition benefits are intended to flow through to the consumers—not to state governments as higher revenue and not to the corporate members of the Business Council of Australia as higher sales and profits, but to the consumers. After all, this is what competition is supposed to be about: delivering a benefit in better prices or greater choice to the consumer. That is something which is often completely forgotten in this debate when many people start talking about `competition' as some sort of an end in itself.

It often seems to me that people aspire not towards getting a better deal for consumers but simply towards creating competition for competition's sake. That frequently proves to be a mistake—especially when we are talking about services or goods which are not responsive to the normal patterns of supply and demand. In any event, the government has failed to include in the bill any statement which reflects the goal of competition benefits flowing through to consumers. The Democrats will be seeking to amend the bill to insert that fundamental principle back into it. Consumer groups also sought to ensure that the government recognised in the bill the necessity for government to continue to look after the interests of disadvantaged consumers. That has not happened either. The government did agree to insert a wishy-washy objects clause and to change the name of the bill, but that was all. There was nothing else.

Even the moderate request from the consumer movement to guarantee that at least two of the members of the National Competition Council have a background in consumer protection was rejected. Under the benchmarks set by the consumer movement the key failing of the bill—and the agreements—is its failure to adequately outline a means of testing the public benefit of competition. The Australian Consumers Association has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Competition policy must be set against the backdrop of the society in which it operates and be in harmony with other social policies. The overall public interest includes such factors as social equity and the natural environment.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly it cannot be simply a matter of administrative fiat to determine pubic interest in assessing whether declarations should be made or authorities granted under the regime.
There must be substantial public consultation and an appropriate degree of transparency in decision making.

Unless consumers can exercise their market power through enhanced choice, education, information, redress and access—unless disadvantaged consumers can continue to obtain fair and reasonable access to essential goods and services—through price, availability and supports—unless the amenity and welfare provided by the built and natural environment is maintained and enhanced—through appropriate regulation, economic instrument and incentive—there can be no net public benefits. Only inappropriate private benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats wholeheartedly support that premise. If the bill and the agreements which underpin it met this benchmark we would support it. That they do not is an indictment on this government and a clear signal that this bill is about private benefits, not about benefit to Australian consumers at large.

PARA.TAB: We note that the government has agreed to an interpretation clause in the competition principle agreement signed by the states which could allow for some of these issues to be considered `where relevant' and `without limiting the matters which will be taken into account'. Of course, I have great doubts that premiers like Mr Kennett in Victoria and Mr Brown in my own home state of South Australia will ever regard issues like the interests of consumers, social welfare and equity considerations or policies relating to ecological sustainability as relevant to their narrow visions of the world. I suppose we should be thankful for small mercies and we are pleased to see at least the inclusion of this weak measure in the agreement.

The bill before us, however, which deals with the legislative changes affecting the federal government's own GBEs, access to infrastructure, and definition of business, contains no such statement. In the committee stage the Democrats will be seeking to rectify this.

The weakening of the former powers of the Prices Surveillance Authority to set up prices in some industries and conduct appropriate surveillance and gather adequate information is one example of how this bill is failing the consumer. Monitoring and reporting is an important activity, but to constrain the ACCC's prices surveillance activities at just this level is to leave it with very few teeth to deal with market failures when they do occur. Of course, looking through the Hilmer rose-tinted glasses we are supposed to believe that competition will ensure that markets do not fail. Of course, only an ideologue would believe in that. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Meeting in Britain

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to make some remarks on a visit that I had the good fortune to make to Britain between Wednesday, 26 April and Friday, 12 May this year. I was a delegate on behalf of this parliament at the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association seminar in London. I want to thank my colleagues in the federal Labor Party caucus and my colleagues in the Australian parliament for the opportunity to attend that seminar, which I found to be not only very informative and worth while but also fairly enjoyable from time to time.

PARA.TAB: I was one of four Australian delegates. The other three representatives were from the states—Mr Patrick Rogan, from New South Wales; Mr Ken McElligott, from Queensland; and Mr Craig Bildstien from Victoria. The four Australians made sure that Australia got a mention in many of the various topics that the seminar addressed during the time that we were assembled—over 2 1/2 weeks.

There were also delegates from Bangladesh, Barbados, Bermuda, Botswana, the British Virgin Islands, Federal Canada, the Cayman Islands, Ghana, the Isle of Man, Jamaica, Kenya, Malawi, Federal Malaysia, the Malaysian State of Sabah, Malta, New Zealand, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Swaziland and Zambia. None of us had met before. That includes the four Australians. At the end of the 2 1/2 weeks very firm friendships had developed between the elected representatives of each of the countries. Because of that development in friendship the links between the countries themselves have been built upon, based on the solid roots that had been in existence prior to the delegation coming together for the seminar.

There were many enjoyable times. When one looks back at these events one tends to reflect, firstly, on the enjoyable moments and perhaps to overlook at the beginning the work that was engaged in during the time the delegates were in assemblies. We did quite a deal of work, particularly when we were based in London. Generally, most of the work was done in the British Houses of Parliament at Westminster.

We were very well looked after by the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association which arranged many excellent speakers and very many entertaining forums for the delegates who had come from diverse backgrounds to take part in the seminar. Unfortunately, as is the case with all these seminars, there was not enough time to debate and discuss fully all the matters that were raised in assemblies. Because we were staying at a hotel that was very close to Westminster we were able to continue many of the discussions, sometimes into the early hours of the morning.

It is difficult to say which was the most important topic, but I would like to comment about the last formal discussion that the seminar engaged in. That topic was the role of the UK in the Commonwealth. It followed that morning's discussion on the Commonwealth and world affairs. The role of the United Kingdom was particularly important. On this occasion the Rt Hon. Baroness Chalker of Wallasey, Minister of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs and Minister for Overseas Development in the British Parliament, led the debate. It flowed on from the earlier discussion on the Commonwealth and world affairs in which Tom Cox, a member of the Labour Party opposition in Great Britain, and Jim Lester, a Conservative Party member, drew a Commonwealth parliamentary perspective of recent world events. One item of particular interest in those topics for discussion was the emergence of South Africa in the world scene and very much into Commonwealth affairs.
The consensus of all delegates assembled was that the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association is a very useful organisation, and long may it reign.

We met with the Commonwealth Secretary-General of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, Chief Emeka Anyaoku; and had some long discussions with the Deputy Secretary-General (Political), Sir Anthony Siaguru KBE. They were very worth while, not only for me but for all delegates. Only the delegates from New Zealand had travelled a further distance than the Australian delegates had. Again, there was not enough time for the dialogue to be fully explored with all the individuals.

Time is not with me tonight. In any case, I do not want to go chapter and verse through all that happened during the 2 1/2 weeks of the seminar. I want to take up my full 10 minutes in recording some thanks. Thanks should go to the organisers of the seminar who worked tirelessly to ensure that all the needs of all the delegates were met, within the limitations of how those needs could be met. I would particularly mention Sir Ivan Lawrence QC MP, who is the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the British Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. They were our hosts. I expressed my personal appreciation to Sir Ivan for the amount of time he gave to the delegation, in meeting with us, attending some of the functions after hours, and then, at the conclusion of the events, again meeting with us and addressing us and answering some questions which from time to time may have appeared pretty silly and stupid to him.

I thank the secretariat which did all the hard work in looking after us on a day-to-day basis. I thank the Secretary, Mr Peter Cobb; the Deputy Secretary, Mr Andrew Pearson; the Assistant Secretary, Mr Christopher Jones; and the Administrator, Mrs Elizabeth Callard. I want to put on record my personal appreciation of them.

I also thank the people who organised things for us in Oxford where we were for two nights and two very full days; and the people in Manchester also need recognition. I will not, because time is against me, record their names.
In looking back now, two months later, the thing that I recall most clearly is the two days on the Isle of Man. The Isle of Man is probably a misnomer.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very sexist.

—It is. I pick up that point. It was one of the first countries to give women the vote. That was in 1881, which was even before South Australia gave women the vote. South Australia was the leading state here in that regard. It was certainly 40 years before women got the vote in mainland Britain. The Isle of Man is very forward thinking, not only because it gave the vote to women early in the piece. Because of its location in the middle of the Irish Sea—it is not part of Ireland—it is celtic in character. It has a native language. Manx is a derivative of one of the celtic languages.

PARA.TAB: Those 2 1/2 weeks were a very fulfilling and a very rewarding two weeks in my life and in my spouse's life. I am grateful she had the opportunity to come along and share some of the experiences and make some of the friendships we made in those 2 1/2 weeks. I express my appreciation formally to the caucus and to the Australian parliament for giving me the opportunity to go there.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 22 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is any Federal Government support provided to the following organisations: (a) Victorian Council for Civil Liberties; (b) the Humanist Society; (c) the Rationalist Society; (d) Gun Control Australia; (e) The Anti Gun Lobby; and (f) the Australian Forum to Control Guns; if so, in each case how much funding is being provided for the 1995-96 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: I have been advised by my Department and relevant portfolio agencies as follows—

(1) (a) Yes, funding is provided by the Attorney-General's Department to the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties in the form of an annual grant. Funding for financial year 1995-96 is expected to be $6,000.

In addition, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission jointly funds the `Get It Right Human Rights' School Program with the Council. It is expected that funding for financial year 1995-96 will be $60,000.
It should be noted that the above reply relates only to my portfolio and information on any possible funding from other portfolios would need to be sought from the relevant Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 29 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service in Queensland paid for the construction of a gymnasium; if so, can a business plan (together with its date of publication) for the gymnasium, showing all costs of construction, equipment, wages and income be provided; if not, can details be provided of total:
(a) capital costs, including construction, equipment and installation;
(b) projected annual income, including membership fees, expenses, cash operating surplus or deficit, non-cash costs and net operating surplus/deficit for the next 3 years;
(c) number or projected number of members from the Australian Taxation Office and elsewhere; and
(d) amount of membership fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in Queensland has met the cost of the construction of a small gymnasium occupying approximately three car spaces in the basement car park. There is no business plan.

The construction of the gymnasium was part of an agreement with staff and unions relating to the relocation of the Brisbane Office from the central business district to Spring Hill. This move produced rent savings of $219,000 per annum.
(a) Besser block construction with fittings—$11,176
Gym equipment—$7,000
(b) No fees are charged. The only cost of the facility is the cost of lighting.
(c) Nil.
(d) Nil.
